text.text: The Pudding presents
You should look at this chart about music genres.
In 2016, Spotify began publishing a chart of popular genres on its platform.
Let’s now fast forward six years later and see how the ranking has changed.
I’ve highlighted the genres that are not among the top 25 in 2016.I wondered why so many genres shifted in popularity.
During my research, I discovered that the real story wasn’t what was popular, but how Spotify thinks about genres.
This is going to take some explaining, so let’s first tackle some obvious trends in the data.
First, music tastes have clearly changed since 2016.
In 2016, k-pop was the 283rd most-streamed genre.
Over the past 7 years, it’s ascended to the 17th most-streamed genre.
Incredibly, k-pop has more streams than R&B and EDM.
You’ve probably heard of Bad Bunny, the world’s most-streamed musician, three years running. Fittingly, reggaeton is the only other genre to exhibit a k-pop-like ascent.
Reggaeton’s ascent should be surprising, which leads me to the next obvious trend in the data.
The geography of streaming is no longer Euro-English centric.
Today, Spotify users from North America and Europe represent a much smaller share of streams than in 2016.
Every year, Spotify is available in more countries. Spotify added South Korea in 2021. And India in 2019. Fittingly, you can see non-English genres begin to dominate in popularity.
Zooming into the top 25, nearly half of genres hail from Latin America, Africa, and Asia.
So those are the obvious insights. With that out of the way, here’s what I really want to talk about: Spotify’s genre taxonomy.
So far, we’ve focused on changes in the top 25.
But the real story is what lies deeper in the data—an ocean of of genres that represent an ongoing attempt to catalogue every music community.
